channel.title: NYT > Science
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 The New York Times Company

item.title: To Get a Man’s Attention, Meow Harder
item.description: In a small study, pet cats greeted male owners with more vocalizations than they did female caregivers.
item.dc:creator: Clarissa Brincat

item.title: Did the Giant Heads of Easter Island Once Walk?
item.description: Scholars have long debated how the massive stone figures of Rapa Nui got to where they stand today. A new study offers one possible explanation.
item.dc:creator: Franz Lidz
item.media:description: The Rapa Nui moai, the monolithic stone figures of Easter Island, were hewed from compacted ash in a quarry inside the crater of the Rano Raraku volcano between A.D. 1200 and 1700.

item.title: NASA Rover Discovers Lightning on Mars
item.description: The Perseverance rover picked up audio evidence of electric discharges in the red planet’s atmosphere.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:description: A towering dust devil casting a shadow over the Martian surface, captured by NASA’s Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter in 2012.

item.title: He’s Beautiful, but He Has a Huge Blind Spot
item.description: Males of two species of pheasants seem to trade attractiveness for the ability to get a good look at predators.
item.dc:creator: Jack Tamisiea
item.media:description: A male golden pheasant in Shaanxi, China.

item.title: U.S. Nuclear Arms Chief Warns Against Leaks of Secret Information
item.description: The email sent to atom bomb officials by Brandon Williams highlights the managerial challenge faced by the former one-term congressman.
item.dc:creator: William J. Broad
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Brandon Williams, the head of the National Nuclear Security Administration, has no deep technical roots or experience in running the nation’s nuclear weapons complex, unlike many of his predecessors.

item.title: Mapping the Brain’s Sense of What Goes On Inside the Body
item.description: Scientists are learning how the brain knows what’s happening throughout the body, and how that process might go awry in some psychiatric disorders.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer

item.title: Seal Milk Is the Cream of the Molecular Crop
item.description: You won’t be drinking it any time soon, but the aquatic mammal’s milk is much more chemically complex than that of other mammals, including humans.
item.dc:creator: Kate Golembiewski
item.media:description: The Atlantic grey seal nurses its young for only 17 days, requiring its milk to be packed with nutrients to quickly prepare the pup for a tough life at sea.

item.title: The Forgotten Nuclear Weapon Tests That Trump May Seek to Revive
item.description: Hydronuclear experiments, barred globally since the 1990s, may lie behind President Trump’s call last month for the United States to resume its testing of nuclear bombs.
item.dc:creator: William J. Broad
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Technicians in an underground test site in Nevada secured the door before execution of the 2021 Red Sage-Nightshade experiment, a subcritical nuclear test.

item.title: In Michigan’s Upper Peninsula, Locals Fight for ‘The Right to Night’
item.description: Industrialization in Michigan’s Upper Peninsula has some residents pushing for protection of the region’s celestial splendor.
item.dc:creator: Katrina Miller and Emily Elconin
item.media:credit: Emily Elconin for The New York Times
item.media:description: The night sky above Eagle Harbor, a village in Michigan’s Upper Peninsula along the shoreline of Lake Superior.

item.title: Beekeepers, Farmers and the Fight to Save a Century-Old Research Hub
item.description: Industry groups and scientists have urged the Trump administration to reconsider its plan to close a renowned Agriculture Department center in Maryland and disperse its work around the country.
item.dc:creator: Linda Qiu

item.title: E.P.A. Delays Requirements to Cut Methane, a Potent Greenhouse Gas
item.description: Oil and gas firms were supposed to start reducing methane, a powerful driver of climate change. The agency is giving them more time and may cancel the requirement.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman and Maxine Joselow
item.media:credit: Desiree Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: A gas flare at an oil facility in Midland, Texas.

item.title: Paul Ekman, Who Linked Facial Expressions to Universal Emotions, Dies at 91
item.description: Often called the world’s most famous face reader, he inspired the TV show ‘Lie to Me.’ But some questioned his assumption that human expressions were ‘pan-cultural.’
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel

item.title: Trump Vowed Fewer Regulations and Lots More Oil. He’s Delivered on One.
item.description: The president’s energy strategy is projected to generate more pollution, but so far production has not risen significantly and price drops have been modest, analysts say.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: Since President Trump took office, oil production is up, but largely because of improved efficiency, and it has not translated into more jobs for either the industry or the overall economy.

item.title: U.S. Announces Negotiated Prices for 15 Drugs Under Medicare
item.description: The Trump administration said that had the new prices been in effect last year, Medicare would have saved $12 billion, which would have reduced its spending on those drugs by 44 percent.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Robbins
item.media:description: The 15 drugs include widely used inhalers, such as Breo Ellipta, and treatments for cancer, diabetes and depression.

item.title: GLP-1 Drug Fails to Quell Alzheimer’s in Novo Nordisk Trials
item.description: The studies were a setback for the optimistic view that semaglutide and other drugs used in obesity and diabetes treatment could help prevent a number of brain diseases.
item.dc:creator: Gina Kolata
item.media:description: A trial of semaglutide, the miracle drug branded as Ozempic and Wegovy for diabetes and weight loss, failed to find any effect of the drug on cognition and functioning in people with mild cognitive impairment or dementia.

item.title: New Studies of Dog DNA Shed Light on Pets and People
item.description: New studies of canine genetics shed light on the diversity of dogs and our longstanding, still-evolving relationship to them.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.category: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences

item.title: Gramma, a Galápagos Tortoise Older Than the San Diego Zoo, Dies at About 141
item.description: Gramma, who died at the zoo on Thursday, was believed to have been born in 1884, when Chester A. Arthur was in the White House.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather
item.media:description: Gramma, a Galápagos tortoise, was “sweet and shy,” the San Diego Zoo Wildlife Alliance said in a statement after her death on Tuesday. She was believed to have lived to 141.

item.title: At the Great Lakes, Unearthing the Submerged History
item.description: Tamara Thomsen, a maritime archaeologist and diving instructor, has helped uncover more than 100 shipwrecks across the region.
item.dc:creator: Shivani Vora

item.title: Study Finds Mental Health Benefit to One-Week Social Media Break
item.description: Young adults who engaged in a social media “detox” reported reductions in depression, anxiety and insomnia, though it was unclear how long the effects would last.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Barry
item.media:credit: Bee Trofort for The New York Times
item.media:description: On average, symptoms of anxiety dropped by 16.1 percent; symptoms of depression by 24.8 percent; and symptoms of insomnia by 14.5 percent.

item.title: These Hospitals Figured Out How to Slash C-Section Rates
item.description: Financial and social incentives can nudge doctors away from the operating room.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Kliff and Bianca Pallaro
item.media:credit: Lauren Petracca for The New York Times

item.title: Lemurs in Madagascar Face an Unexpected Killer
item.description: Thousands of the endangered primates end up on the dinner plates of people in the upper rung of the country’s society who have money to spare.
item.dc:creator: Dina Fine Maron
item.media:description: A bamboo lemur (Hapalemur occidentalis) eating bamboo.

item.title: COP30 Climate Summit Ends With Dire Warnings and Scant Plans for Action
item.description: The final agreement, with no direct mention of the fossil fuels dangerously heating Earth, was a victory for countries like Saudi Arabia and Russia, diplomats said.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak and Lisa Friedman
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: The closing session of the COP30 climate negotiations in Belém, Brazil, on Saturday.

item.title: Eli Lilly, Drug Maker of Zepbound and Mounjaro, Reaches $1 Trillion in Value
item.description: The 150-year-old drugmaker is the first company in health care to hit the milestone.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Robbins
item.media:description: Eli Lilly, based in Indianapolis, has surged in large part because of the company’s success in commanding the GLP-1 weight loss drug market.

item.title: Cassidy Got Pledges From RFK Jr. on Vaccines. They Haven’t Stuck.
item.description: Before casting a crucial vote for the health secretary, the top Senate Republican laid out several specific commitments he had secured, some of which appear to have been breached.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Bill Cassidy during a committee hearing on Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s nomination to be health secretary in February.

item.title: RFK Jr. Says He Instructed CDC to Change Vaccines and Autism Language on Website
item.description: In an interview, Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. cited gaps in vaccine safety research. His critics say he is ignoring a larger point: Vaccines save lives.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: It is highly unusual for a health secretary to personally order a change to scientific guidance, but Robert F. Kennedy Jr. ordered the language adjustment on the C.D.C. website.

item.title: China Offers Panda Totes, but No New Commitments, at Climate Talks
item.description: The United States has retreated on climate. China, the only superpower at COP30 and the world leader in clean energy, is not filling the void.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman and Somini Sengupta
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: The China pavilion of the COP30 conference in Belém, Brazil, last week.

item.title: Saturn’s Rings Seem as if They’re About to Disappear: Here’s Why
item.description: During the weekend, the orbits of Earth and Saturn will combine to create an interplanetary optical illusion for anyone with a good telescope and clear skies.
item.dc:creator: Tom Metcalfe
item.media:description: Saturn’s rings, observed by the Cassini spacecraft. They will be all but invisible when viewed from Earth on Sunday.

item.title: Fine Chocolate in Brazil, Home of the Cacao Bean
item.description: A new generation of craft chocolate makers in Brazil is creating bars with “identity.” And they’re helping to sustain the forest, too.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta and Alessandro Falco
